pButton.Name: GOVERN and DEFEND
pButton.popInfo: The amount of territory and power a nobleman could claim was closely related to how many people that nobleman was sworn to protect.

pButton.Name: TERRITORY
pButton.popInfo: There was constant feuding amongst neighboring nobles, fueled by envy of the wealth and possessions of those in neighboring manors.

pButton.Name: TITLES
pButton.popInfo: Many of the first nobles were descended from Germanic chieftains. Newer nobles distinguished themselves in battle to earn titles, such as duke, earl, count, baron, and marquis.

pButton.Name: ROYALTY
pButton.popInfo: From the greater nobility will emerge a group known as “royalty” by the end of the Early Middle Ages. They earned this rank through distinguished leadership on the battlefield – with a promise of many more victories to come. The “royals” would have the loyalty of many nobles.

pButton.Name: CEREMONY
pButton.popInfo: By the eighth century, some rulers were ceremonially armed with a royal scepter. Once crowned, kings and Kaisers claimed to rule by divine right (or at God’s will). Their sacred role signifies Christianity’s dominion over medieval Europe.

pButton.Name: POWER
pButton.popInfo: By the early modern era (around 1400) strong sovereigns will seek ways to escape the Vatican’s control.
